posts.title: First post
posts.text:
Hello World, 
 I have been recommended to start documenting my progress in programming. This blog is meant to document that process. 
 Last week was my first week back to HTML and CSS in about a decade. I first started using HTML for my MySpace page in 2008 or 2009 and continued on to make websites from 2010 - 2012. I would like to thank my late friend David Braun for his friendship and mentorship. He helped me many times when my code would break in CSS, and JS. 
 Through university courses I learned the basics of C++ and Python. I quickly forgot them. 
 My life has taken me in many directions but I find myself with a strong urge to immerse myself in tech. My current goal is to get a job in Web Development. My plan is to thoroughly learn the tech stack of HTML5, CSS3, and JS. Eventually I want to relearn MySQL and PHP and I have intentions on using them in some future projects. 
 Last week I started with following a YouTube tutorial on creating a portfolio page. It went well and I learned a lot through the process. This was the first time I had ever used hsl and the first time I had ever used color as a variable. In my past experience I had given each element to be colored a hexcode, and upon the need I would go through the entire document changing the hexcode for each element. Fun. 
 I also noticed that their attention to media quieries was much greater than mine. I remember making very basic media quieries that would neglect to alter image size or text size when the screen ratio was adjusted. Back then I had only heard of one CSS framework 'Skeleton' and I started using it towards 2012. Before that I had neglected to include anything that would resemble today's responsive designs. 
 Last week I also began a free course at freecodecamp.org for responsive web design principles. It covers HTML basics, CSS basics, and some accessibility features. HTML5 brought some new features such as the header, nav, main, section, and footer tags. I also learned how to make gradients in CSS which blew my mind. I used to create images to give my website the appearance of having a drop-shadow or gradient. I also remember creating a horizontal rule by drawing a 1px black line in Gimp and placing the image into my HTML page. 
 I have a day left before I will finish the first part of the course and then I will start on creating a few very basic projects. After that I will be moving on to JS.
